Data Structure: All measurements are stored in a single SOFA dataset (e.g., a matrix of impulse responses) together with spatial dimensions and metadata. Full details: https://www.sofaconventions.org/mediawiki/index.php/SOFA_conventions
Coordinate System: Listener-centric spherical coordinates as defined by SOFA convention. Azimuth increases counter-clockwise around the listener (0° = front). Elevation increases with height above the listener.
Notes: Refer to Supported SOFA Conventions for compatibility list.

Data Structure: All measurements are stored in a single .npy array per listener using the spatial format: [elevations][azimuths][channels][samples].
Coordinate System: Elevation increases with height (min = elev = max, midpoint = listener level). Azimuth increases counter-clockwise (0° = azim < 360°, 0° = front). Channels: L, R.
Notes: Variable sample length, Stored at 44.1 kHz.

Data Structure: SOFA files conform to the selected SOFA convention. WAV exports include: direction-specific stereo BRIRs (one file per source direction); true-stereo BRIRs (4 channels: LL, LR, RL, RR); HeSuVi BRIRs (14 channels, 24/32-bit, 44.1/48 kHz); and 16-channel FFMPEG-compatible BRIRs.
Coordinate System: SOFA: as per SOFA convention. WAV: positive elevation = above listener, negative = below; zero = listener level. Positive azimuth = right, negative = left.
Notes: Exported as SOFA BRIR datasets or WAV BRIRs. Refer to Supported SOFA Conventions for compatibility list. Variable elevation limits and angular resolution depending on spatial resolution. Refer to Spatial Resolutions for valid ranges and grids.

Data Structure: Files may contain any number of channels and samples, with arbitrary bit depth and sample rate.
Notes: Used as raw acoustic space data prior to internal transformation.

Data Structure: Each space is stored in a separate .npy array with dimensions: [listener_locations][source_locations][channels][samples].
Each response is stored in a separate .npy array with dimensions: [channels][samples].
Targets are stored in a single .npy array with dimensions: [target_id][samples].
Notes: Stored as minimum-phase FIRs at 44.1 kHz.

Data Structure: Filters are stored in a single .npy array with dimensions: [filter_id][samples].
Headphone correction filters are stored as frequency-domain responses in dB with associated metadata in SQLite databases.
Notes: ASH database and compilation database use slightly different schemas.

Data Structure: Export formats include: mono minimum-phase FIR WAV; stereo minimum-phase FIR WAV; 127-band graphic EQ; 31-band graphic EQ; and HeSuVi-compatible 127-band graphic EQ.
Notes: Exported as minimum-phase FIRs or graphic-EQ parameters, depending on format.
